document.docOrigin: Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History 2010 (345)
document.masterDocTitle: The Andean Goblin Spiders Of The New Genera Niarchos And Scaphios (Araneae, Oonopidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Andean Goblin Spiders Of The New Genera Niarchos And Scaphios (Araneae, Oonopidae)
Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History

paragraph.keyLead:
1. Males (those of
baehrae
,
grismadoi
,
matiasi
, and
rheimsae
unknown)............. 2

– Females (those of
keili
and
florezi
unknown)......................... 19
2. Dorsal scutum covering most of abdomen .............................. 4
– Dorsal scutum covering cardiac area only (figs. 407, 430)................... 3

3. Dorsal scutum relatively long (fig. 407).........................
michaliki

– Dorsal scutum relatively short (fig. 430)............................
ligiae
4. Palpal bulb with retroventral projection (as in fig. 17)......................... 5
– Palpal bulb without retroventral projection........................... 11

6. Embolar region relatively narrow (figs. 221, 224)........................
florezi

– Embolar region relatively wide (figs. 198, 201)...................
wygodzinskyi
7. Anterior projection on endites narrow (figs. 151, 174)................... 8
– Anterior projection on endites wide (figs. 12, 35, 128)........................ 9

8. Embolar region relatively long (figs. 176– 179)........................
elicioi

– Embolar region relatively short (figs. 153– 156)........................
tapiai

9. Endites with rounded protrusion just posterior of anterior projection (fig. 128), chelicerae with distinct anterior projection (fig. 126)...
keili
– Endites without rounded protrusion, chelicerae otherwise.................... 10

10. Embolus relatively long, thin (figs. 36–40).........................
barragani

– Embolus relatively short, thick (figs. 13– 17).......................
cotopaxi
11. Embolar base bent near middle at right angle (as in figs. 234, 395)............... 15
– Embolar base not bent near middle at right angle.......................... 12
12. Embolus relatively short, with translucent tip (figs. 569, 665)................... 13
– Embolus relatively long, with dark tip (figs. 462, 485)................... 14

13. Translucent tip of embolus relatively long (figs. 664, 665)..............
facundoi

– Translucent tip of embolus relatively short (figs. 568, 569)..............
palenque

14. Embolus accompanied by long, basal projection (figs. 461, 462)...............
loja

– Embolus without basal projection (figs. 484, 485)........................
foreroi

15. Embolus bearing long, narrow distal flange (figs. 395, 396)...............
santosi
– Embolus without narrow distal flange.... .............................. 16

16. Embolar base relatively thick (figs. 234, 235).......................
scutatus
– Embolar base relatively thin (as in figs. 319, 344, 369)....................... 17

17. Anterior projection on endites relatively small, directed medially (fig. 368), terminal palpal elements triangular (figs. 374, 375)............................
vegai
– Anterior projection on endites larger (figs. 318, 343)................... 18

18. Projection on embolar base relatively large (figs. 319–325)................
ramirezi

– Projection on embolar base relatively small (figs. 344–350)...............
bonaldoi
19. Sternum surface finely reticulate (as in fig. 46)......................... 20
– Sternum surface smooth (as in fig. 246).. 28
20. Genitalia with anteriorly expanded anterior process (figs. 474, 677).............. 21
– Genitalia without such a process...... 22

21. Genitalia with translucent atrium (figs. 677, 678)......................
facundoi

– Genitalia without translucent atrium (figs. 474, 475)......................
loja
22. Genitalia with thumblike anterior process (figs. 27, 119, 384)................. 23
– Genitalia without thumblike anterior process........................... 25

23. Thumblike process extending anterior of receptaculum (fig. 385)............
vegai
– Thumblike process not extending beyond receptaculum (figs. 27, 119).......... 24

24. Posterior extensions of thumblike process diverging at wide angle (figs. 119, 120).........................
barragani

– Posterior extensions of thumblike process diverging at narrow angle (figs. 26, 27).........................
cotopaxi
25. Genitalia with distinct apodemes (figs. 143, 166, 189)....................... 26

– Genitalia without distinct apodemes (figs. 211, 212)...........
wygodzinskyi
26. Anterior receptaculum containing distinct lateral ducts (figs. 143, 166).......... 27

– Anterior receptaculum without lateral ducts (figs. 188, 189)................
elicioi

27. Epigynal atrium triangular (figs. 142, 143)..........................
baehrae

– Epigynal atrium ovoid (figs. 165, 166)
tapiai
28. Genitalia with thumblike anterior process extending anteriorly of receptaculum (figs. 310, 334, 359, 405)................ 29
– Genitalia without thumblike anterior process........................... 32
29. Anterior margin of anterior receptaculum medially indented (figs. 310, 334)...... 30
– Anterior margin of anterior receptaculum medially smooth (figs. 359, 360, 405, 406) .............................. 31

30. Sclerite connecting apodemes narrow at midline (fig. 335)..............
ramirezi

– Sclerite connecting apodemes wide at midline (fig. 311)....................
scutatus

31. Apodemes present, connected by wide sclerite (fig. 360)...................
bonaldoi

– Apodemes absent (fig. 408)......
santosi
32. Anterior receptaculum with M–shaped anterior protrusion (figs. 428, 451)........ 33
– Anterior receptaculum without anterior protrusion......................... 34

33. Posterior sclerite of genitalia oval (figs. 428, 429)......................
michaliki

– Posterior sclerite of genitalia rectangular (figs. 451, 452).................
ligiae
34. Anterior receptaculum enlarged, membranous, with short anterior sclerotization (figs. 687, 697)................... 35
– Anterior receptaculum not enlarged.... 36

35. Anterior sclerotization of anterior receptaculum relatively narrow (figs. 687, 688).............................
grismadoi

– Anterior sclerotization of anterior receptaculum relatively wide (figs. 697, 698)................................
matiasi

36. Apodemes longer than epigastric scutum (figs. 707, 708)..............
rheimsae
– Apodemes much shorter than epigastric scutum......................... 37

37. Anterior genitalic process greatly widened anteriorly (figs. 654, 655).......
palenque

– Anterior genitalic process not greatly widened anteriorly (figs. 559, 560).........
foreroi
